coredata.dc:title: Multiple-scattering analysis of the X-ray absorption spectrum of Os3(CO)12 carbonyl cluster
coredata.dc:creator: Filipponi, A.
Di Cicco, A.
Zanoni, R.
Bellatreccia, M.
Sessa, V.
Dossi, C.
Psaro, R.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
A new theoretical approach has been used to analyze the X-ray absorption cross section of Os3(CO)12 carbonyl cluster. The method is based on a direct fit of the experimental cross section which makes use of theoretical signals associated with relevant atomic configurations in the molecule. In the case of the OsCO arrangement, it has been found that the commonly employed multiple-scattering series converges slowly at low k values; the calculation has, therefore, been performed using a more efficient continued-fraction algrithm that provides the “exact” signal summed to all orders. An excellent agreement in the range k=2.7–14.0 Å−1 has been obtained, basically using X-ray diffraction results.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 184, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 October 1991 Dipartimento di Fisica, Universita degli Studi del/A quila, Via Vetoio, 67010 Coppito - L Aquila, Italy A. Di Cicco Dipartiinento di Mateenalica e Fisica, Universita degli Studi di Camerino, Via Madonna delle Carceri, 63032 ( amerino (MC), Italy R. Zanoni, M. Bellatreccia Dipartiniento ai Chirnica, (]niversita di Roma La Sapienza Piazza/c A/do Moro 5, 00185 Ro,ne, italy V. Sessa Dipartinzento di Scienze e Tecnclogie Chimiche, 11 Universit a di Rama Tor Vergata ~ Via O. Rai,nondo, 00173 Rome, Italy C. Dossi and R. Psaro Dipartimento di Chimica Inorganica eMeiallorganica and Centro CNR, Universita di Milano, Via G. Veneziari 21, 20133 Milan, italy Received4 June 1991; in final form 8 July 1991 A new theoretical approach has been used to analyze the X-ray absorption cross section of 0s3(CO)2 carbonyl cluster. The method is based on a direct fit of the experimental cross section which makes use of theoretical signals associated with relevant atomic configurations in the molecule. In the case of the Os C=O arrangement, it has been found that the commonly employed multiple-scattering series converges slowly at low k values; the calculation has, therefore, been performed using a more efficient continued-fraction algorithm that provides the exact signal summed to all orders. An excellent agreement in the range k= 2.7 14.0 A~ has been obtained, basically using X-ray diffraction results. Molecular metal clusters provide the highest size- selected way of investigating both size and adsorp- tion effects. Metal carbonyl clusters represent the largest known class of binary molecular clusters. Sev- eral different geometries have been reported: car- bonyl clusters with terminal, edge- or face-bridging CO ligands have been described. X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) has been widely applied to pure and supported molecular clusters, particularly to metal carbonyl clusters [I 11]. The advantages of performing data analysis by using the curved-wave formalism [12], have been pointed out in a study on several Os carbonyl clus- ters [1,2] where the sensitivity of XAS to locate non- bonded metal metal distances was assessed. This analysis produced particularly satisfactory results in the case of larger clusters, where the number of metal neighbors exceeds the C=O contribution that cannot be reproduced appropriately by using a single-scat- tering (SS) theory. The necessity to include multi- ple-scattering (MS) effects up to the triple-scattering order has been emphasized in a more recent paper [91 on cobalt carbonyl complexes. A detailed anal- ysis of the MS effects as a function of the Co C=O angle was presented, showing the possibility of dis- tinguishing between bridging and terminal carbonyl groups. A detailed description of the fitting proce- dure using the EXCURVE program and based on ef 485 0009-2614/91/$ 03.50 t991 Elsevier Science Publishers BY. All rights reserved. Multiple-scattering analysis of the X-ray absorption spectrum of Os3 (CO)12 carbonyl cluster A. Filipponi CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 October 1991 Volume 184, number 5,6 Fourier filtering. The noise of the measurement is not suppressed. The Os3 (CO ) 12 structure is known from X-ray diffraction studies [22]. As far as the XAS analysis is concerned, the environment of each Os atom can be schematically represented by: (a) a first Os C shell, (b) a more distant Os Os shell, (c) the oxygen atom contribution in the collinear Os C=O configuration, (d) contributions from O or C atoms at higher distances, (e) three-body contributions from two distinct C neighbours of an Os atom. Other geometrical configurations contribute with higher frequencies and can be neglected. The signal in (e) has been found to be small and is neglected in the present treatment. The two-body contribu- tions arising from (a), (b) and (d) can be treated at the .X2 level, the largest higher-order correction being the Os C ~ contribution. The oxygen contribution described in (c) gener- ates many MS signals, in addition to the Os O SS, which are particularly relevant in such a collinear ar- rangement. The standard MS analysis is usually lim- ited to double-(X3) and triple-(~4) scattering signals because of computational difficulties; in our opin- ion, this truncation of the MS series is not sufficient in the present case. In fig. 1, the Os O SS contri- bution is compared with some MS paths of different orders: the convergence of the MS series with in- creasing x order is not evident at all. In particular, the X3 and X4 paths are comparable in amplitude with higher-order paths, in the low-k range. Higher-order paths may be reasonably neglected above k=5 A~, but below this point, most of the paths up to the .Xo order must be included. Due to the large number of paths, the interpretation of the signal in terms of the MS series may become rather cumbersome. For this reason, we found it more convenient to work with exact signals resummed to all orders. Our novel ap- proach has consisted of evaluating the difference from two total calculations a(Os C=O) o(Os--C), which, by definition, corresponds to the actual ad- ditional contribution due to oxygen. In terms of the MS series, this signal corresponds to the sum of all the SS and MS contributions arising from both the Os O two-body and the Os C=O three-body config ficient expressions for MS terms [13], has been re- ported. Successive investigations based on the MS curved-wave theory have dealt with supported Ru carbonyls [101, and iron carbonyls in solution [111. In this paper, we investigate a species represen- tative of the most important class of pure and sup- ported carbonyl clusters, group VIII metal carbonyl clusters, taking into account the new theoretical ad- vances in the calculation of X-ray absorption cross- sections. The present investigation deals with Os3(CO)12, which best exemplifies the interest de- voted to carbonyl clusters in the literature on sup- ported molecular metal clusters, since it preserves the triangular metal frame when supported on numerous substrates. 0s3(CO) 12 has been synthesized according to lit- erature methods; [14] its purity has been checked against literature spectra [151. The X-ray absorp- tion spectrum at the Os L3 edge (10837 eV) was re- corded during dedicated beam-time at the PULS (Frascati) Synchrotron Radiation Facility using a Si (Ill) channel-cut monochromator. Data analysis has been performed using the re- cently implemented GNXAS package [16] which explicitly takes into account MS effects to any order in the scattering. Previous applications of GNXAS have dealt with amorphous silicon [17], simple mol- ecules [16,18] and high-T. superconductors [19]. Heavy metals and large molecules can be also han- dled, affording an analysis of the XAS spectrum free from adjustable empirical parameters. Three major advances of the GNXAS package over previous methods are as follows: (1) The model for the potential is built according to the Hedin Lundqvist plasmon-pole approxima- tion [20] for the self-energy part of the optical po- tential which allows one to take account automati- cally of the photoelectron mean free path. (2) SS and MS signals are classified according to the appropriate n-body distribution functions. It is possible to calculate directly the total signal due to a particular n-body arrangement either by means of a partial summation of the MS series up to the X6 or- der, or directly to all orders using a continued-frac- tion expansion algorithm [21]. (3) The fit of the experimental spectrum is per- formed directly as energy versus absorption, so that there is no need for background subtraction and 486 Volume 184, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 October 1991 Fig. I. Comparison between the Os O Z2 signal and the first terms of the MS series involving the Os (1), the C (2) and theO (3) atoms. urations, to all orders. It should be noted that the main contributions have the same frequency of the Os O distance in Fourier space, the effective oxygen contribution being, therefore, a damped oscillation as the Os O SS, but with completely different am- plitude and phase. Such a single signal, hereafter re- ferred to as oxygen total signal 9(0), is repre- sentative of the O contribution and these results are both more rigorous and more convenient than the MS series. From the computational point of view, the exact inversion of the I GT matrix has been performed using the continued-fraction expansion and the recursion method, until convergence was reached [21]. All of the abovementioned signals have been cal- culated with their amplitudes and phases as well as the appropriate derivatives with respect to the geo- metrical parameters. Successively, they have been used to fit the experimental absorption spectrum and to derive mean geometrical parameters and Debye WaIler terms. It should be noted that in this corn- pound, the previously described (b) and (e) signals fall in the same frequency range. In order to dis- criminate between the two contributions, it is essen- tial to include a large k interval in the fit and to treat correctly the configurational average. Our analysis scheme correctly takes into account the configurational damping of a general MS of re- summed signal. It is known [23] that such a damp- ing is not given by a simple exp( ak2) term; ad- ditional amplitude correction and dephasing terms should be included. In particular, the damping of the oxYgen contribution due to the static or dynamic broadening of the Os C=O angle departs consider- ably from an exp( ak2) behaviour, as demon- strated hereafter. The configurational average of the signal is cal- culated performing a Taylor expansion of both am- plitude and phase functions with respect to the geometrical variables, around the equilibrium con- figuration. The first derivatives of amplitude and phase are indicated with A1 and v ~~ respectively. The second derivatives, which have to be included be- cause of the extreme position of the angle in collin- ear paths, will be A2 and V~2~ The damped signal is then given by [23] ~=Im(A0 exp(i~0) X [I (i/A0) (A 1,d/dii1) (1) The factor A0 exp(i~i0) is the undamped signal. The symbol W(1te1) represents the Fourier transform of the probability distribution of the geometrical vari- ables times an additional factor exp [ ~ i (r, ~2r)], ac- counting for the second-order dephasing, calculated for argument ~ If ~/~2 can be neglected, W(~,1) re- duces to the characteristic function of the probabil- ity distribution. Let us assume the distribution to be Gaussian with a covariance matrix M. It is easily found that det (Q /2) det(A~fl 2) (2) where Q~ =M~ iqi2, in matrix notation. Let us define the geometrical coordinates for the Os C=O arrangement as the Os C bond length, the C=O bond length and the 180 angle Os C=O. For exactly collinear configurations, the first derivatives with re 0 5 10 15 20 k (i ) 487 Volume 184, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 October 1991 spect to the angle vanish; therefore, the second de- rivatives A ~ and ~ic~ are relevant. The remaining sec- ond derivatives can be neglected because the first derivatives do not vanish. The angular symmetry, moreover, splits the matrix M of the Gaussian dis- tribution into a 2x2 block n , associated with the bonds, and a further diagonal element o~ (angular), because the bond length and angle coordinates are uncorrelated. Specializing the above equation for such exactly collinear configuration, we obtain: ~=Im{A0 ~ X [l+(i/A0)(A~, m~i1)+A~a~/2A0] Xexp[ ~(W, myi1)]} (3) In this expression, the damping factor is complex, the imaginary terms introduce a dephasing of the sig- nal, as well as an additional, non-Gaussian, modi- fication of the amplitude, as anticipated. An appropriate account of the structural or ther- mal damping is essential for a correct interpretation of the signal in this model compound and especially in unknown systems where various hypotheses on different bonding geometries need to be tested. Our approach is totally new and certainly satisfactory in this respect. The result of the fit of the experimental spectrum in the range k= 2.7 14.0 A~ is shown in fig. 2. From top to bottom, the Os Os X2, the Os C X2, two more distant Os C and Os O X2 signals, the total oxygen contribution i~(O), and the Os C X4 are shown. The following curve shows the comparison between the total theoretical signal and the experiment. The two curves practically coincide, thus showing the ex- tremely high quality of the analysis. The last curve is the difference between experiment and theory and basically contains only statistical noise. The agreement between experiment and theory is also evident in Fourier space: in fig. 3, the magni- tudes of the Fourier transforms (FTs) in the range k=2.7 l4.0 A are compared. The FT of the re- sidual signal is very small. The shape of the Fi spec- trum reveals a fairly intense Os C first-shell peak followed by an even stronger second peak due to both oxygen and osmium. In the higher-frequency re- gions, only very weak contributions are observed, justifying the adopted cutoff in the included atomic 2.5 5 7.5 10 12.5 15 k (A~) Fig. 2. Results of the fit of ihr spectrum ofOs3(CO)12 with the theoretical signals as described in the text. The agreement be- tween theory and experiment is excellent as shown in the last two curves. L o e Q) Q) L z o o ~0 z e Q) R (.) Fig. 3. Magnitude of the Fourier transform of the experimental, theoretical and difference spectra. The agreement is spectacular in R space as well. ( ) experiment; (_ ) theory; ) residual. configurations. The non-zero FT magnitude at small R values would indicate a poor background subtrac- tion in the conventional EXAFS analysis. In our case, where a direct fit of the absorption data is per- formed, it is due to the non-zero average of the sig- nals in the given k range. Figs. 2 and 3 best exemplify the potentialities of Xz(O~ OQ)) ~ (O~ C=O) 3 4 5 488 Volume 184, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 October 1991 phasing of the order of 0.1 rad is found. The rele- vance of these small corrections has to be compared with the difference between experiment and theory which is around l0~ jump units. The perfect agreement in the interval k=2.7 14.0 A is obtained basically using crystallographic data and represents the level of accuracy of the theory. The relevant fitting parameters are summarized in table 1 and compared with diffraction results when possible. Resulting distances are very close to the average values of the known crystal structure. The error in the present analysis is of the order of 0.01 A, usual for the standard EXAFS analysis but not in the pres- ence of relevant MS contributions. Only with the in- clusion of the Os C=O MS signal to all-orders and with the correct configurational average given by eq. (3), is it possible to obtain highly reliable values for the structural parameters. The values for the mean-square relative displace- ments cannot be compared with direct measure- ments; however, the static contribution can be cal- culated from diffraction data, and the thermal contribution can be calculated using an effective Einstein model for the bond vibration for localized modes, The Einstein stretching frequencies for the C=O and Os Os have been estimated from IR of Raman spectra [24 26] to be 2050 cm- and 150 200 cm , respectively. The corresponding thermal var- iances are reported in table 1. The comparison between estimated and measured values is rather good, in agreement with the statis- tical error on a2 values. It should be noted that our method allows one to estimate the true a2 values, while in standard analysis, one can measure only dif ferences with respect to some reference value, The fit has been performed by assuming a negli gible correlation between the Os C and C=O stretch ing, which is certainly reasonable, considering the large frequency differences of the respective vibra- tional modes. The Os C=O angle distribution was modeled as Gaussian around a mean value of 180 ; its variance is reported in table 1 and is partly due 10 12.5 15 to static contributions. The high sensitivity of our analysis to the Me C O orientation and possible variation from a linear arrangement, has strong implications in the XAS in- vestigation of supported species: the cluster support our analysis method based on the theoretical mo- delling of the absorption spectrum including MS ef- fects on carbonyl clusters. The oxygen total signal is very intense up to large k values, and is mainly due to MS terms essential for the explanation of the spectrum. The importance of a correct account for the con- figurational average is shown in ltg. 4, where the log- arithm of the damped/original amplitude ratio ver- sus k2 (a) and the dephasing versus k (b) due to the angle average are plotted for the total oxygen signal. Chem. 19(1980)1961. interaction implies partial loss of carbonyls and a subsequent structural reorganization of the residual CO molecules, driven by the electron density on the metal cage and by the coordination number of single metal atoms. Often, this interaction results in the breakdown of the cluster frame in ensembles or mononuclear surface species, with a significant change in the catalytic properties. Therefore, the ac- tuai role played by CO ligands in the initial inter- action of the cluster with the surface groups on the support may be elucidated with our data-analysis procedure. head.ce:title: Multiple-scattering analysis of the X-ray absorption spectrum of Os3(CO)12 carbonyl cluster

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: A new theoretical approach has been used to analyze the X-ray absorption cross section of Os3(CO)12 carbonyl cluster. The method is based on a direct fit of the experimental cross section which makes use of theoretical signals associated with relevant atomic configurations in the molecule. In the case of the OsCO arrangement, it has been found that the commonly employed multiple-scattering series converges slowly at low k values; the calculation has, therefore, been performed using a more efficient continued-fraction algrithm that provides the “exact” signal summed to all orders. An excellent agreement in the range k=2.7–14.0 Å−1 has been obtained, basically using X-ray diffraction results.
